PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 22 August, on motion by Senator Gareth Evans:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition will support the Building Industry Bill, and indeed will aid its expedition. It is not without some obvious reluctance in the Government that this Bill has come to fruition today. Certainly even in this last week we have seen considerable confusion in Government factions and in the Caucus of the Australian Labor Party in determining the attitude to the legislation to outlaw the Builders Labourers Federation. I understand that the Caucus passed by only the slimmest margin the motion supporting this Government legislation.
—How would you know what goes on?

—One has only to look at Victoria to understand the pressures that exist in that State between factions, obviously demonstrating a lack of support and will in the ALP to address itself to this legislation. But more of that later. There is no doubt that the BLF in its activities over the last 10 to 15 years has shown the unacceptable side of unionism for all Australians to see. All the worst aspects of unionism have been clearly shown to Australians. I refer to flagrant disregard for arrangements, contempt of courts, industrial blackmail and coercion, thuggery, victimisation of individual union members. It has given unionism the worst name that it could possibly have earned under any other circumstances.

SPEECH.PARA: These points do not have to be made by the Opposition in debate. They have been made quite clearly by the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) in his second reading speech when he dealt with the kinds of actions that have occurred in the last few years as perpetrated by the leadership and the members of the BLF. It is not as if those objectives have been clothed with some kind of legitimacy aimed at attempting to bring about some kind of industrial reform. Many of the activities carried out by the union have been of a political nature, obviously with political objectives in mind. I was pleased to see that the Minister in his second reading speech drew attention to that particular matter. He said:

The record shows that from this time the union has had scant regard to these undertakings. It has, on a multitude of occasions, engaged in the kind of conduct it repudiated before the Court, and its industrial record contains numerous examples of harmful demarcation disputes, broken concrete pours, violent conflicts with police and fellow unionists and disruptive campaigns over non-industrial issues.

We all know the political colour of the leadership of the BLF, its pro-communist leadership and its obvious attempt to get involved in political activity outside the industrial regime. Clearly, that is at the heart of the activities of this union over the last few years. I refer to the Winneke Royal Commission into the Activities of the Australian Building Construction Employees and Builders Labourers Federation, which reported to the Government on 27 May 1982. I quote from page 280 of that report, which again demonstrates the problems in dealing with the BLF in the last few years:

Not only has it ridden roughshod over the obligations imposed upon it by the Conciliation and Arbitration Act but it has paid scant respect to the duties imposed upon it by the general law of the land, civil and criminal alike. Under the pretext of `promoting the interests of its members, this organisation has, with frequency, resorted to tactics of violence, intimidation and victimisation.

Further in this report it is demonstrated quite clearly how the unions set about achieving those ends through deliberate actions. Let me quote from a chapter on page 333 dealing with industrial techniques adopted in the field by the Federation. These remarks were attributed to a Mr Steve Black, the New South Wales Branch Secretary, in his bulletin to members of September 1979. Under the heading of `Guerrilla Tactics' Black wrote:

The tactics used to get the overaward payments and better conditions are `guerrilla tactics'-the use of bans and lightning stoppages to disrupt the boss on the job. These tactics include: lightning strikes, work to rule, banning of parts or sections of jobs, one day and one week bans on concrete, stopping of concrete before a pour begins, breaking of concrete pours, bans on mobile cranes, bans on the lifting of certain materials by cranes or hoist, bans on truck deliveries, bans on unloading trucks, sending trucks away, overtime bans, safety bans, bans on the removal of scaffolding.

These tactics and others are designed to hit the boss in the pocket. Rather than costing B.L.'s wages in lengthy strikes, the boss loses the money when the bans are used. This is a policy of `the most harm to the boss the least harm to ourselves'.

That is the kind of tactic employed by the BLF to obtain objectives which this Government, through its Minister, has now admitted are not merely industrial actions designed to improve the standards of living of the workers of the union but obviously have other objectives-political obviously being among them.

I will briefly run through the history of the BLF in the last 10 to 12 years. It should be remembered that the BLF was first deregistered as a union in 1974. However, it was reinstated in 1976 and became a registered union once again on the specific undertaking given by the then Secretary-and perhaps he is still the present Secretary-Mr Norman Gallagher, that in fact the union would abide by orders of the court and abide with the law. Those undertakings were broken time after time as the union continued on its merry way of employing the industrial tactics that I have outlined. It was at the Fraser Government's initiative in February 1981 that deregistration proceedings were again instituted in the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. That being a long-winded procedure, it proceeded up until the time of the election of the Hawke Labor Government, which immediately upon coming to office in March 1983 stopped those proceedings. The reasons given at that time were that the problems of the building industry had to be cured by discussion and by other kinds of debates and initiatives, presumably by the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations getting together with the unions and the employers and bringing about some kind of resolution. Two and a half years after those talks the Government has finally realised that it has to put its shoulder to the wheel and face up to its responsibilities.

We are not going to say that we told it so, but it is clearly part of this Government's failure to come to grips with the real problems in this country that it has not recognised that it should have continued that action 2 1/2 years ago rather than letting the water flow under the bridge as it has, bringing about more economic difficulty, more economic cost to the country and, of course, disruption to the lives of individuals in the meantime. That is the failure of this Government and it can be traced right back to 1981 when Mr Hawke, who was then the official spokesman for the Labor Opposition on industrial relations-he had not yet ascended to his great position of power as Leader of the Party-debated this issue on television on 18 February 1981 with the then Industrial Affairs Minister, Mr Andrew Peacock, the now Leader of the Opposition. I shall quote from that Nationwide transcript. When Mr Peacock was challenged in that debate about how the dispute should be handled, he replied as follows:

Now on the point of talk, there has been a great deal of talk and there's been a great deal of talk by Mr Gallagher producing hit-lists or his spokesmen as well against Government projects, against State and Federal Government projects and if there was an opportunity to talk and bear in mind that Bob-
that is, Mr Hawke-

tonight in his introduction was not prepared to hold a brief for the builders labourers and I don't blame him, he can't condone their action. But if there was a question of solving their behaviour by discussion he had every opportunity when he was President of the ACTU to try and draw them into line. I do not see that he has succeeded.

There is the point: From 1969 to 1980, when he became the honourable member for Wills, the present Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) was President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, and all the talking in the world with the Builders Labourers Federation came to nought. Surely that was lesson enough for the Prime Minister and for this Government to take action, and to resume the action initiated by the Fraser Government in 1981 to deregister the BLF. But no; upon coming to government in 1983 he returned to the talkfest, seeking some kind of consensus with a bunch of ratbag criminals who run the BLF. So it is that he again has let the country down by not taking action at the time he should have.

The Prime Minister can retrieve the situation. Let us look at the dispute now at Mudginberri, a most important dispute that goes to the core of industrial affairs in this country. An arrangement between employees and an employer in the interests of economy, in the interests of jobs and in the interests of exports and efficiency in this country in the production of new meat products for which there is a demonstrable market overseas is being stopped by the action of a trade union. That trade union's membership, of course, comprises people employed by the Commonwealth Government. The meat inspectors picketing on Commonwealth land at Kakadu are Commonwealth employees who are stopping an efficient industry from proceeding and creating more wealth for all Australians to enjoy. That dispute, more than any other, demonstrates the weakness of this Government and is really a sidelight to the dispute going on with the BLF. But now what can we expect from the Prime Minister on this? Is he going to talk about Mudginberri for another 2 1/2 years before he takes action? There will be another industry down the drain and more economic cost to the country, just as we have witnessed over the action that has not been taken in timely fashion by this Government in respect of the BLF.

Let us just turn very briefly to this legislation. The legislation provides the Minister with enormous and various powers to take action to deal with the Builders Labourers Federation. We do not deny that those powers should be vested in the Minister. But I think we should realise that they are very powerful indeed. They provide almost draconian and certainly dictatorial powers to the Minister to choose whatever line he seeks to take to deal with the BLF. We do not say, in the circumstances of this dispute, this problem with the BLF, that that should not be done.

As we have said, we support the legislation. But I must say that I am somewhat bemused that the Government sees fit to obtain the passage of legislation such as this which has at its core the solution of the economic problems of this nation. Presumably the Government is acting in what it perceives to be the best interests of the public, yet a matter of weeks ago the Government introduced into this House legislation to override legislation passed by the State Government of Queensland which sought exactly the same kind of conclusion by ensuring that electricity supplies were guaranteed to the people of Queensland. There is an exact parallel here. This Government saw fit to challenge, for political purposes, the Premier of Queensland and the action of the Queensland Government. Yet it does exactly the same thing in respect of the Builders Labourers Federation and claims it to its credit. How can the Government reconcile those viewpoints? It cannot, because the action taken against Queensland was for purely political purposes. We know that and we have had those debates in the Senate over the last several weeks. We have demonstrated clearly from this side of the House how pusillanimous the Government's action was at that time when it tried to bring about some kind of political change in Queensland that was not in the interests of either the electricity workers or the people of Queensland generally.

TALK.START.PARA: —Come on! You don't know much about it at all, do you?

—I am just pointing out the hypocrisy of Senator Georges's Party. He understands those points; I know he does, because he is one of the few on that side who are honest. The last point I want to make in this respect is in regard to the BLF itself. We can recall that not long ago, during this period of talk that the Prime Minister is supposed to have been undertaking with the union, the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations being seen publicly to be advocating to the building unions, of which the BLF is one, the seeking of wage settlements outside the accord, not in the form of ordinary wage increases but in the form of some kind of superannuation. He advocated that they should obtain contributions from employers, to which employees would not contribute, to the establishment of funds, which really amounted to deferred wages and not superannuation.

SPEECH.PARA: The object was clear: It was the circumvention of the award to try to buy off the unions from future action, to establish what is now known as the BUSS, or the builders unions superannuation scheme. The whole thing is a fraud, but that is another argument again. The point is that until very recent times-at least within the last 12 months-the Minister has been advocating that kind of action by unions in circumvention of the wages accord with the ACTU. That is how much respect this Government has for its own arrangements with the ACTU. That is how much respect this Government has for the affairs of the people. That is how much respect it has for the economy of the country. Of course, it has no respect at all, as demonstrated in the half-Budget introduced this week.

We see before us then a government confused and divided by its own factions, struggling to hold on to some kind of credibility in the area of industrial affairs. Everybody knows that in the end it is the ACTU which calls the tune. Here we see some token effort by this Government to introduce legislation to attack that union which represents the most unacceptable side of trade unionism. We support the legislation, but we fear what else this Government can do, will do or will fail to do in the future, because when the crunch comes it will be its union masters who will decide how it will behave.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats support the Government's move to deregister the Builders Labourers Federation. Over a long period the actions of this union have been totally irresponsible and have done great damage to the building industry. Time and again the BLF has ruthlessly pursued its own interests by any means possible with complete disregard for the effects of the resulting disruption on the rest of the community. Senator Messner instanced some of the tactics that have been applied by this union such as calling a strike in the middle of a large concrete pour, which means that jackhammers have had to be brought in the next day to chip away hundreds of tonnes of concrete. The BLF has also engaged in tactics such as Norm Gallagher's guaranteeing that if crane drivers joined the BLF he would triple their wages within 12 months. They joined and he did, by holding every building site in the country to ransom.

SPEECH.PARA: Initially the Government was planning to move promptly against the BLF. Now the plan is to send the matter to the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission for judgment. Should the Commission decide that the behaviour of the BLF warrants deregistration, the Government will act. I accept this course of action but with very strong reservations. I have no quarrel with bringing in the Commission to act as an umpire. Indeed, it would be a very dangerous precedent for the Government to deregister a union without bringing in an impartial body. To do otherwise would amount to the Government acting as prosecution, judge and jury. This is not something that anyone with a commitment to justice would be pleased to see. If this were done, it could well encourage conservative governments to act against unions for reasons of purely political expediency. The Liberal and National parties have a long record of making political mileage out of union bashing and we would not like to see this practice encouraged.

I have a nagging suspicion that the Government is attempting to put any action against the BLF on the backburner by sending the case to the Arbitration Commission. Since the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) first announced what action would be taken against the BLF there has been considerable disquiet within factions of the Australian Labor Party and the union movement generally. It would be a travesty of justice if the Government allowed feuding in its own ranks to prevent action being taken against this rogue union. The first step in the direction of a backdown would be an attempt to drag out proceedings in the Commission. The next step could well be the dropping of the case altogether after public interest has dissipated. I do not think it is unreasonable for the Australian Democrats to ask the Government whether it can give us any indication as to the anticipated length of the reference to the Commission in this case. Perhaps Senator Ryan would like to take notice of that question. We believe that the Government must show that it is serious about taking the BLF to task by ensuring that the Arbitration Commission proceedings take place as quickly as possible. The ground work done between 1981 and 1984 in the previous deregistration case should, wherever possible, be used by the Commission to speed up proceedings. The Government must act upon the findings of the Commission and not be swayed by good behaviour arguments of the BLF. When the chips are down the BLF can behave itself, only to revert to its old ways when the opportunity presents itself.

It is not only the Government that must maintain its backbone on this issue. Employers have a bad record in this area too and the history of deregulation of the BLF bears this out. The last deregulation case against the BLF was commenced by the Fraser Government in 1981 due largely to complaints by employers about the actions of the BLF. The case dragged on until 1983 when the Federal Government pulled out and it was finally abandoned altogether in 1984 when the employers pulled out. The reason the last case was so protracted was largely the ambivalence of the employer bodies. The employers made a big noise for action to be taken. However, when it came to actually supporting the case, giving evidence and perhaps antagonising the unions, they became weak-kneed. They wanted the Government to do their dirty work.

TALK.START.PARA: —What absolute rubbish.

—I am afraid that the record bears this out. The dropping of the case by the Hawke Government in 1983 was largely due to the lack of support by the employers. If the employers now believe there is a strong case against the BLF they must come forward and give absolute backing to the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: The trade union movement is also open to charges of hypocrisy after its on again-off again support of deregistration proceedings. The BLF has acted very badly towards other unions in the past. Members have been poached, demarcation conflicts have flared and violence has been used against members of other unions. The Australian Council of Trade Unions has been highly critical at times of the BLF but it has been unwilling to take any action against it. I am afraid that the unions want it both ways. They want to reap the benefits of BLF-won conditions in terms of flow-ons and industry norms but they do not want to take action against any injury to their members by BLF tactics. The Government, to its credit, is not proposing to conduct its own kangaroo court. It is taking this matter to the umpire for a dispassionate and independent judgment. Therefore, those unions with real grievances against the BLF should also support the case and not merely adopt a knee-jerk reaction that `the Government is merely union bashing'. This is a critical matter.

I believe that the case against the BLF is overwhelming. The BLF has used its industrial strength to further its own ends at the expense of the community. Let us have a brief look at the history of this case. In 1982 the Winneke Royal Commission into the Activities of the Australian Building Construction Employees and Builders Labourers Federation painted a very black picture of the operations of the BLF. Bribes and secret commissions were said to be commonplace. Interest free loans were given to BLF officials. Corruption, it seems, is not limited to the better known members of the BLF.

The Loy Yang dispute was a long and costly affair for the Victorian Government and Victorian taxpayers. The provision of a new power station for the Victorian State Electricity Commission cost far more than was originally estimated and took longer than planned, in part due to the disruptive tactics of the BLF. The BLF pursued a log of claims in the Loy Yang dispute with crippling bans on the five main contractors working on the site. Things became so bad in fact that the contractors withdrew from the site and no work was carried out from April to December 1980. The dispute was not resolved until the State Government made a `hardship' payment to the labourers stood down even though it was widely accepted that the BLF had arranged for work elsewhere for those on strike. The taxpayers had to foot the bill for the strike over some years at Loy Yang which was caused by the BLF.

Not all BLF tactics have been directed towards employers. The 1983 scissor lift dispute is a prime example of BLF violence against other unionists. Scissor lifts were introduced on building sites in the early 1980s. Because they replaced scaffolding in some circumstances-and this was a BLF preserve-the BLF wanted to control them. Tradesmen objected, claiming that they were the ones who used them and therefore they should operate them as tools of their trade. The dispute which followed was exceedingly bloody and resulted in the BLF being disaffiliated from the Victorian Trades Hall Council, no less. In this case unions took action against the BLF, yet they are ambivalent about the Government doing the same thing.

The dispute over the building of the light towers at the Melbourne Cricket Ground last year was just another example of BLF aggression towards other unions. The Arbitration Commission awarded that work to the Federated Ironworkers Association of Australia. The BLF claimed that it should do the work and imposed pickets which caused considerable disruption and expense. May's V. C. Transport Pty Ltd, the company which moved the steel sections from the fabrication plant to the site, eventually went broke due to BLF bans.

The union has constantly flouted wage guidelines and gone for pay increases outside the normal channels. Endless pledges of good behaviour have been broken as soon as the opportunity presented itself. Last year, following a period of industrial unrest in the building industry, the industry's code of conduct agreement was restored and peace prevailed for a very short time. This agreement has been broken 100 times by the BLF since it was introduced. From all the evidence which is readily available it seems obvious to me that the case against the BLF is irrefutable.

I urge that proceedings in the Arbitration Commission be carried on as quickly as possible. It is also vital that the responsibility for carrying on the case is not left solely to the Government. All interested parties must stand up and be counted. This Bill, as Senator Messner said, clearly gives the Government the opportunity to act, not to act or to act in part. I am afraid that the monkey is very squarely on the shoulders of the Government at this point. The responsibility, once this legislation is passed, will be entirely the Government's. Other members of the other interested parties in the community should stand up and support the Government but in the final analysis it is the Government that has to take the initiative. We hope it does.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the Building Industry Bill strongly and with some passion. The Builders Labourers Federation, by its own actions, placed itself long ago outside of the wider labour movement. The actions of the BLF have gone far beyond the scope of normal industrial behaviour. Its continued use of guerrilla tactics, thuggery, violence and intimidation against ordinary union members as well as employers can no longer be tolerated. The years of violence must end. The union movement has shown in recent times, as well as in times past, its own abhorrence of the tactics used by the BLF. It is fully aware that the BLF has placed in jeopardy the hard fought conditions of the broader union movement. It is fully aware that the BLF has put at risk the whole of the arbitration and conciliation system. It has become sadly aware of just how anti-worker the BLF has become. If a person is not a member of the BLF and he works on a construction site, certainly in the cities of Sydney, Melbourne and Canberra, he is in big trouble. But even if he is in the BLF and he dares to speak out and disagree, he is in the same sort of strife.

SPEECH.PARA: The Labor Council of New South Wales recently passed a resolution condemning the industrial record of the BLF. It called on the union movement to cease from assisting the BLF in any attempt to deregister it. The New South Wales Labor Council has had a long history of dealing with the BLF. We have to go back only 11 years to 1974 to see just how the BLF can perform. On one ordinary meeting night-a Thursday night-at the Labor Council, as the delegates were debating the normal course of business suddenly the doors flew open and in came the first wave of BLF thugs. In the first few minutes of that assault they showed just what sort of people they are. Old Jack Ryan, at the time the Assistant Secretary of the Federated Rubber and Allied Workers Union of Australia, a veteran with a wooden leg, was the first to be attacked. A chair was smashed over his head. That is the sort of people we are dealing with. How anyone can defend that as reasonable union behaviour I do not know.

It has taken many people in the New South Wales Labor Council a long time to come to a final decision about the BLF. They have had to weigh up their feelings for the history of our movement and for the right of workers to band together to get better conditions against a continuing record of criminal and violent behaviour. The decision was taken only after many delegates wrestled with their conscience. But 11 years on, the resolution condemning the BLF passed at a meeting attended by 200 delegates to the New South Wales Labor Council, was opposed by only a few dissidents in the back row. The whole of the labour movement was united against the BLF. Those union delegates, of course, have had plenty of experience of, shall we say, on the job training, of learning just what the BLF can be like. The union movement has had enough of that thuggery that has been waged against other unions as well as the 35,000 members of the BLF, but particularly the percentage of the BLF that works in the cities of Sydney, Melbourne and Canberra.

The Australian Council of Trade Unions executive on Monday carried a 700-word resolution which clearly distanced itself from the BLF. The ACTU resolved not to provide collective protection to the BLF if the union, in turn, created the extreme circumstances where other unions were not prepared to accept its legitimacy. Cliff Dolan, in a public statement, said:

The ACTU cannot and will not give unequivocal support to the BLF and its activities. The ACTU is not prepared to act as a guarantor to the BLF commitments in view of the questions raised as to their compliance to these agreements.

For the union movement to take such a stand against one of its own indicates how strong and deep the feeling runs. The BLF has been a threat to our movement's reputation as well as being a threat to the physical safety of ordinary workers. The BLF has belied the trust that the Government, the union movement, the employers and the community have placed in it. Once again it asks for one more chance. It tells us that this time it will behave. It tells us that this time it will be responsible. If we are going to judge on past experience, the BLF has had its chance. Every time it has given the undertakings to be responsible it has lied. We can go back to 7 October 1976 and the re-registration undertakings given to the Industrial Registrar. Norm Gallagher, in speaking to the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, said:

I can further submit that the Commission can properly and confidently assume that the policy of this Federation is to resort to conciliation and arbitration through the Commission rather than direct action in breach of the Act or in breach of awards of the Commission.

Let us have a look at the history of the BLF since that time to see whether Mr Gallagher and his cohorts kept the undertaking. In September 1981 the Fraser Government lodged a deregistration application with the Federal Court of Australia. In April 1982 the BLF imposed bans upon Victorian builders involved in the deregistration case. In April 1983, after looking at another year of industrial anarchy, the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, Mr Willis, convened a meeting with building industry employers and union representatives to seek alternatives to deregistration. The Government was to give the BLF one of its many chances. An agreement was reached between the Government, the BLF, the Master Builders Association, the ACTU and the Federation of Construction Contractors. In May 1983, in response to this, the BLF agreed to a moratorium on industrial and punitive action. In October 1983 the BLF gave an undertaking to the Commission that it would not seek further claims outside the national wage increase, so as presumably, at some stage of the game, to get that increase. In February 1984, the BLF placed bans on sites, particularly the State Bank site in Sydney, as part of a campaign to get an extra $9 a week which was in clear breach of the undertaking given to the Commission. Prior to that, in December 1983, the Government had gone to the Federal Court to seek leave to withdraw from deregistration proceedings.

So the Government had given the BLF several chances over that period. It had tried again and again. Throughout 1984 activity in the BLF ran riot and got out of control. I refer to events at the Alcan site at Granville in April and the Melbourne Cricket Ground site in May. In September 1984 the BLF invaded the Australian Workers Union offices in Melbourne. In October 1984 the campaign started at the police centre site in Sydney which, along with the Qantas Building and a few others, was a classic example of BLF unreasonableness, violence and guerrilla tactics. On 12 October 1984, a mass meeting of unions condemned the BLF's conduct. In October 1984, in response to this, the Premier of New South Wales, Neville Wran, announced the establishment of a police task force to look into allegations against the BLF and announced the deregistration of that union in New South Wales. BLF work bans continued on sites in Sydney and Victoria. On 2 January 1985 the New South Wales Government gazetted its decision to proceed with deregistration against the BLF.

Let us look at what the BLF undertook in December 1983 when it reached an agreement with the Government and the various other bodies. It said that it `recognised that such registration creates duties and responsibilities in registered organisations . . . to utilise the means provided by the Act for the prevention and settlement of industrial disputes'. The record that I have just outlined indicates how much force the BLF gave to the undertaking. It was, of course, like all of its other undertakings-just one more lie to get just one more chance to continue with its activities. On 30 January 1985 the New South Wales Labor Council called on BLF members to ignore work bans and, failing that, directed other unions to complete work without BLF personnel. I refer to the police centre site in Sydney. The typical BLF picket line was crossed day after day by members of trade unions that were not always united in their aims and political views but were united in their desire not to be stood over by a rogue union.

On 5 July Neville Wran called upon the Commonwealth and the ACTU to deregister the BLF. On 8 July 1985 the Victorian Government under John Cain announced that it would take action. On 23 July the Cabinet, meeting in Canberra, approved the concept of legislation on de- registration, I again quote from the Press release of Ralph Willis of that day:

The actions of the BLF had gone far beyond the bounds of normal industrial behaviour. Their guerrilla tactics and use of thuggery, violence and intimidation have had a disastrous impact not only on building employers but also on fellow workers in the industry.
The BLF's behaviour poses a threat to the continued existence of the union movement.

If we look at some individual cases of how the BLF has acted against other workers on building sites and how it has performed, we will start to get a real idea of the sort of union that it has become. The first and I think the most relevant case to look at is the Sydney police centre site. We must acknowledge at least one success for the BLF on the police centre site and on a number of others. The BLF was successful in having a benevolent Almighty arrangement for the rate of industrial accidents to zoom up rapidly whenever an official from another union came on to the police centre site and a number of other sites. If a union official visited the site to service his members you could bet your life that an accident would occur. Unfortunately, for some of those officials, it was indeed their lives that they were betting. During the worst part of the dispute, over the last Christmas-New Year period, an official of the Building Workers Industrial Union of Australia walked on site and a concrete bag happened to fall off the top of the building and miss him by inches. Not content with accidents and not prepared to rely on the Almighty, when the dispute was at its worst BLF members went to the upper floors of the site and threw bags of concrete and lumps of steel at those workers working down below. It was a miracle that on that occasion no one was killed, but plenty of people were injured. As workers from the BWIU, the plumbers union and other unions crossed the picket line, they were kicked and bashed. Anyone who attempted to go across the picket line, even though it was a picket line not recognised by the ACTU or by the New South Wales Labor Council, was subjected to that form of assault and thuggery.

It got worse. The BLF then resorted to what had been hitherto, as far as I was concerned, a practice anathema to all members of the labour movement. It began a practice of taking photographs of everyone who crossed the picket line so that it could threaten further action against them and their families. The registration numbers of their cars were noted. Photographs were taken every day as any new person dared to walk across the line on his way to work. The cars of union officials were regularly subjected to damage and attack. Hundreds of dollars worth of damage was caused to quite a number of the cars of officials, particularly of the BWIU. Union officials and their families were subjected to threatening phone calls in the dead of night. Besides those tactics unsanctioned work bans were then put on other sites right across Australia. Over 40 sites were affected in New South Wales and over 50 major building sites were affected in Victoria.

I refer to the incident which took place at the Criterion Hotel in Sydney, which is not, one would say, the normal work place or a place where the war would be carried on. A few officials of the Plumbers and Gasfitters Employees Union of Australia had the temerity to gather there after work for a few drinks. They were soon interrupted by a crowd of BLF heavies and they too were bashed as they had a drink at the bar. Once again the BLF went outside the normal confines of reasonable industrial behaviour and engaged in further criminal activity. The action of its members against fellow unionists is now regularly carried on away from the building site. If the BLF is going to get you it will get you anywhere. That is what it tells workers every day of the week-that is, any worker who dares to disagree.

The Theme Park in the outer western suburbs of Sydney is another good example. It is a large amusement centre site on which over 800 workers from Sydney's western suburbs are employed for the construction stage. The BLF closed that site for 19 days because the tradesmen had the gall to remove a `Free Norm' sign from the site. Before the site was closed the BLF illegally removed parts of the scaffolding to prevent any of the other workers from going to upper levels. While the dispute proceeded anyone who attempted to work beneath the scaffolding was simply pelted with concrete and steel to make sure he left the job. That tactic has been used again and again.

In recent times the off-the-site tactic I find most abhorrent is in relation to money grabbing or money grubbing, depending upon one's point of view, and again in absolute breach of normal union principles. I refer to the use of debt collectors to hunt down people who have left the industry. A quaint rule in the BLF is that an employee must notify the union in writing that he has left the industry. The employer cannot do it. Obviously, in an industry such as the building industry that is difficult. It has a very large number of people from ethnic communities working in it who do not read or write English. These people are subjected to this law which is applied to everybody else. If they leave the industry and go on to other employment debt collectors are sent to hunt them down, summonses are issued and it is insisted that they pay back union dues, even if they can prove that they have not worked in the industry for the period involved. That sort of practice is just not on in pretty well all Australian unions.

At least the accidents in the Greater Union site in George Street, Sydney, were different from the ones at the police centre site; it was not concrete bags that continually fell but lumps of steel. Again, a BWIU official had to jump out of the way as steel came crashing down. In another incident a BLF member-he had been engaged in a number of assaults and intimidation against other members-brought a rifle on to the site. When he was asked why he needed to bring a rifle on to the site he replied, quite simply: `I am going shooting on the weekend. It is for that'. That is not a bad answer. We could all accept it except for the fact that it was Monday morning. The weekend was a long way away and this man wanted to have a gun on the site for the whole week.

A BLF organiser called at the College of Advanced Education, Campbelltown, and ordered a stop work meeting on what his own members regarded as a very minor issue. The BLF members on the site defied the organiser's order. They regarded it as a trumped up dispute and kept working. I think they will probably rue that day. The organiser returned with a few of his comrades and proceeded to wreak havoc on the site. The bricklayers' levels and tools were destroyed, electricity to the cement mixer was cut off, mortar was spilt all over the site and all those working on it were chased off. The real problem, is of course, that one cannot expect ordinary rank and file members of the BLF to come forward and give evidence when they are subjected to this sort of intimidation. The workers on this site and the other sites that I have just mentioned all fear for their safety; they have all feared for it more than once. These incidents occur again and again. One cannot expect them to solve the problem; the problem will have to be solved by combined government and trade union action. If one talks to the officials of other unions one realises that that is the only way the problem can be solved and hopefully it will be by this Bill.

There are numerous other incidents of BLF violence against small builders on small sites. They occur all the time; they are commonplace in Sydney, Melbourne and Canberra. Builders have little choice but to bow to the BLF and retrench whoever it tells them they have to retrench. Builders are subjected to foundations being destroyed whenever it is discovered that they have someone on-site of whom the BLF does not approve. Builders have to bear that cost, a cost that has grown over time.

Therefore, by introducing this legislation the Government is calling for an immediate hearing in the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission so that it can make its own independent determination on whether or not all of these well documented incidents have occurred. If the Commission decides that they have occurred, the Minister and the Government can take action and the union can be deregistered.

The legislation sets out a number of criteria which will be an appropriate test of whether the Federation has behaved as a responsible organisation registered under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act and in a way which is consistent with the objectives of the industrial relations system. I have no doubt that the BLF cannot pass such a test. If it fails it, what is essential in this dispute over the coming months will be support for whatever the Government does, not just from the community but from employers.

I am heartened by the gallup poll published this week on the front page of the Melbourne Herald which suggested that 69 per cent of people support the Government's moves to deregulate the BLF, only 18 per cent are opposed and a further 13 per cent have no opinion. But more than just that sort of community feeling and community support we need to know that employers will, on this occasion, resist intimidation, resist being stood over and stand up to the BLF. Too often over time employers and developers have been prepared to do separate sweet-heart deals with the BLF against the interests of the industry as a whole. As Ralph Willis said, employers have adopted industrial relations practices which have facilitated the success of the BLF's tactics. This time employers must remain firm in their resolve. They must create a suitable industrial environment, a code of behaviour in the industry, a code of behaviour the other unions and themselves will stick to. I remind honourable senators that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has called on building employers to do this. He warned that the Government would take action against employers, such as refusing them government contracts, if they continued to co-operate with the BLF if it was deregistered.

Many times the New South Wales ALP administrative committee, of which I am a member, debated whether the BLF should be deregistered. In New South Wales the BLF has not been affiliated with the Party for the last five or six years. It sought reaffiliation only this year. As a result of a decision of the Party's National Executive, the New South Wales branch of the Party was forced to accept the union. I think all honourable senators would know that the New South Wales Administrative Committee is made up of some strong minded people who do not always agree. Yet on this occasion in a long resolution concerning the BLF its decision was unanimous. All of the groups within my Party who are represented on that Committee came to a unanimous decision. The wording of the resolution of the New South Wales ALP Administrative Committee is strong. It stated that as a consequence of the actions of the BLF:

. . . the NSW ALP is of the view that all sections of the labour movement should reject and condemn the philosophies and practices of the BLF which involve violence and intimidation. To do otherwise casts a shadow over the entire labour movement.
There is ample room in the Australian political and industrial environment for legitimate trade union activity. There is no room however for intimidation and thuggery.

It can be seen from all of the incidents I have outlined in my speech that the BLF is no ordinary union and that is why extraordinary action is required. BLF leadership-at least in New South Wales, Victoria and the Australian Capital Territory-does not draw its inspiration for its industrial and political activity from the traditional heroes of the labour movement. It does not draw its inspiration from the Tolpuddle Martyrs, Keir Hardie, Ernie Bevin, Peter Lalor or Jim Healy but rather from people such as Beck and Jimmy Hoffa. It uses the tactics and techniques of New York muggers. It is the duty of the Government and the whole of the labour movement-indeed it is the duty of our community-to ensure that this blight on the movement is done away with and that ordinary workers can get about their work without fear of their person, without fear of intimidation and without fear of assault.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The speech made by Senator Richardson was the biggest indictment of the Australian Labor Party I have ever heard. Why did we not hear such a speech in 1981 when we moved for deregistration of the Builders Labourers Federation? Nothing has changed since then. I think that speech was the biggest indictment of the Labor Party ever in the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: It is important that we go through the history-as most honourable senators have done-of the BLF. I will start with 17 February 1981, a day on which a speech such as Senator Richardson's should have been made by members of the Labor Party. On that day Mr Fraser announced a decision to commence deregistration proceedings against the BLF. On 18 February, one day later, Mr Hawke said `No, don't do it. Let us sit down and talk.' Senator Richardson's description of the BLF today told us nothing new about that union. Such behaviour by the BLF has been going on for years. What action did the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), the then Leader of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, take at that time? He did absolutely nothing. He did not sit down and talk with the BLF. He did not make the ACTU haul the BLF into line. At that stage he said that we should all sit down and talk. On 5 March 1981 the industry employers joined with the Fraser Government. The Age newpaper reported:
A national meeting of building industry employers has decided to back the Federal Government's application to deregister the Builders Labourers' Federation.
The National Industrial Construction Council decided yesterday to provide the Government with information to help . . . the Federal Court.
At that stage, Mr Peacock, who was the Industrial Relations Minister, was reported by the Age as saying that he hoped the decision would:
`nail for all time the lie that employers will not support the Government in its deregistration application'.
But it did not. The Government is still talking the silly rot that the employers did not assist. On 14 April it was reported in the Canberra Times that:
The department and other government departments have been swamped by industry response in support of the deregistration.

Later that year it was maintained that 488 claims against the BLF had been made by the industry. However, in the debate today we have been told that the employers did not support the Government. What utter rubbish! What rot! On 26 September 1981 deregistration proceedings were started. Meanwhile of course the Winneke Royal Commission was inquiring into the activities of the BLF. The Winneke inquiry into Activities of the Australian Building Construction Employees and Builders Labourers Federation reported in 1982. I will read a short excerpt from that report which said of the BLF that:

It has paid scant respect to the duties imposed upon it by the general laws of the land, civil and criminal alike. Under the pretext of `promoting the interests of its members' this organisation has, with frequency, resorted to tactics of violence, intimidation and victimisation. Resort by the victims of these tactics to the ordinary processes of the law has been met with recrimination and . . . arrogant assertion-
The Commission reported that the Secretary of the New South Wales branch of the union had stated in an official publication:
`builders labourers in Sydney have won some big victories recently through the use of `guerilla tactics'-
The union official had said that these would continue. The BLF publication is reported as further stating:
`The union does not tolerate any police interference in industrial matters.'

Indeed, it says much the same things that Senator Richardson has said today. All those things were known in May 1982. On 8 November 1982 the Full Bench of the Federal Court commenced hearings of a joint application-I stress joint application-by the Federal Government and the employers of the building industry. We know that in February 1983 Norm Gallagher was jailed for contempt of court. On 5 March the Hawke Government came to power. On 21 March, just under a fortnight later, Mr Hawke applied for an adjournment of proceedings on the deregistration application. He said that they would talk. The parties talked and talked. Many promises were made. As honourable senators will remember, we had an economic summit. Norm Gallagher was released from jail to attend the summit. That shows the sort of Government we have in power at the moment. During this time the talks continued.

By 12 December 1983 so many promises had been made by the BLF and so much talking had been done that the Labor Party, under Mr Hawke, withdrew from the deregistration proceedings. Senator Siddons has said that employers did not assist the Fraser Government with the deregistration of the BLF. That is not true because whilst the Labor Government withdrew from deregistration proceedings in December 1983 the employers did not withdraw until 18 July 1984. The employers had been dumped by the Government and snowed by the Government and the ACTU telling them that the BLF would abide by all the promises it had made. What followed all that promising and all that talking? I will quote from the speech of the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis), who put the matter pretty clearly when he said of the BLF:

Its use of tactics such as breaking concrete pours, reckless application of work bans, resort to walk-offs or `homers', and claims for payment for time on strike, has made industrial relations in the industry a nightmare. Its resort to industrial blackmail, thuggery, violence and intimidation has added a further ugly dimension to its activities.

According to the Minister all that activity followed the talks and the promises. We know that following July 1984 and all the promises Norm Gallagher finally was jailed for four years and that the BLF continues to make problems. These were the grounds the Minister used for deregistration. What were the grounds we used for deregistration? We used exactly the same grounds; there is no difference. We had done this five years earlier. The cost to the industry in that intervening five years has been thousands of millions of dollars. In that time this Government has stood by and allowed that to occur. Indeed, it encouraged that unrest to occur by its withdrawal from the deregistration proceedings we had in motion.

Mr Hawke said that the reason he did not continue with the initial deregistration and why we were wrong in instigating the proceedings was that the ACTU and other unions would not support them. What are the ACTU's comments now? The executive will not support the Labor Government in its deregistration moves. Cliff Dolan makes it clear that that is against its policy. What is the reason for Mr Hawke going ahead with the deregistration proceedings? I can say only that we were fortunate to have a by-election coming up in Nunawading in Victoria. Mr Hawke and Mr Cain both knew from the polls of which Senator Richardson spoke today that the community was behind deregistration. So they moved, in a political manner only, to deregister that union.

Mr Hawke has now backed off again. He has decided that because he does not have the support of the ACTU he will allow another group to take the action that the Government should be taking, He has given the BLF another chance. The Labor Party will not agree that that is the result of this legislation. If it does not agree perhaps the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations could say why the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission exists if it does not have the right to allow the BLF to retain its registration. Why are we putting through this legislation? Senator Siddons said that the Government has bowed out and given the responsibility to the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. No action at all would have been taken if there had not been that crucial by-election in Victoria. Mr Halfpenny, a good Labor Party member, is demanding an inquiry into the gaoling of Norm Gallagher and opposing the deregistration of the BLF.

While we support this Bill we believe that it is the Government's responsibility to act to protect the population against everything which Senator Richardson claimed was happening. It was a very good speech. It pointed out just what the union has been up to. But it is the Government's responsibility to protect the population against those sorts of tactics and the Government will not accept that responsibility.

Once again, the Government has backed off because the ACTU will not support it, which has proved that the ACTU has so much power over this Government that it is not willing to accept its responsibilities. It has backed off and given the responsibility to the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. It has said: `If you find that the builders labourers should remain registered we will abide by that decision and we will not move to deregister them'. It seems to me to be absolutely inconceivable that the people of Australia would accept that. They showed in the Victorian by-election just last week that they want a government to govern properly. Yet the Cain Government is now being called to bow to the likes of Mr Halfpenny. The left wing of the Labor movement wants an inquiry into why Norm Gallagher has been gaoled and is moving against deregistration.

I suppose that we are left with exactly what we expect from all Labor governments, that they will kowtow to those who supply the money, to those who call the tune-unelected representatives-and bow to a non-elected group once again which is saying: `Back off. Do not make the decision. We will appeal to the Arbitration Commission on behalf of the unions'. Indeed, that is the action that the ACTU intends to take.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Georges Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is fairly obvious that someone ought to intrude some opposition to the Building Industry Bill and I will do so. We have heard strong speeches in support of the Bill and no criticism of it except to say that it does not go far enough. Perhaps the speech that I am about to make should not be made. But it is certain that the speech made by Senator Richardson ought not to have been made because the problems of the trade union movement are problems which it should settle. Government intrusion in the form of this Bill will not improve the situation. My view is that the legislation will exacerbate the problem and create more industrial disputation and confrontation. My view is that it will be challenged continually and by that means it will be made ineffective.

SPEECH.PARA: The problem with this Bill is that once introduced it will never by repealed. It is directed against one organisation. One could question whether it can be so directed. Nevertheless, it is. It would take only a slight change for it to be directed against other organisations. This Government will never be able to withdraw the legislation, having in mind the numbers in the Senate. It is fairly obvious that the legislation that has been presented does not seek to achieve a purpose and then go out of existence. I would like to be convinced otherwise. It is here to stay. It creates a procedure which can be used by a government hostile to the labour movement-the trade union movement. It can be used by that government to even greater effect. These words of caution ought to be introduced into this debate because there is a movement to conservatism in this country, to extreme right wing politics.

TALK.START.PARA: —Showing up the Labor Party all right.

—Yes. Look at what is happening in Queensland. It will seek not only to deregister a union but completely to deregulate the whole of the trade union movement. That is the purpose that the Opposition would have in mind, if it ever came to government, to dismember completely the trade union movement. My view is that this legislation dismembers the BLF and creates a precedent that others will follow.
—You do not think that these are unique circumstances?

—The circumstances are unique. They need to be corrected. The circumstances were going through changes that would achieve that end. In this sort of situation we need to have patience. Honourable senators may say that sufficient patience has been exercised as far as the BLF is concerned but this legislation and the attempt by government to intrude are destructive not only of the trade union movement but also of the commissions which supervise and adjudicate.
—What about--
—That is my view of it. Senator Walters has her view and it seems to have sympathetic responses on this side of the House. That alone ought to raise a very big question.
—Are you going to cross the floor?
—Is the honourable senator going to call for a division?
—We are supporting the Bill.
—Of course; everyone appears to be supporting the Bill.
—Have your name recorded against it.
—Perhaps I need another.
—No. You can call for a division.
—Senator Vallentine may help you out. Perhaps you could argue--

—I ask honourable senators not to divert me because I want to say some words in support of the BLF. I can only do so because of my own experience with the union; that is, my experience with it in Queensland.
—Very good.

—It is exceptionally good. Vince Dobinson's leadership of the BLF in Queensland, and that of his Executive, has been exemplary. The Queensland branch has good relations with a variety of other unions in Queensland and the employer organisations have no extremely critical comments to make beyond the normal opposition they have to all trade unions in their endeavour to better their conditions. What we need to do-the Bill endeavours to recognise this but it will not be able to achieve it-is to separate the Builders Labourers Federation in Queensland because of its good record. Men like Vince Dobinson within the builders labourers organisation, not only in Queensland but also in other States, could lead to the change that some honourable senators seek to precipitate but will not succeed in achieving. Changes are taking place. Leaders in the BLF have been brought to account for certain acts. Gradually the environment in which the BLF operates and the way in which it operates are changing. They ought to be allowed to change. One could now ask: Why is the situation in Queensland different from that in New South Wales and Victoria?
—Your moderating influence.

—I suggest that the problem exists within the trade union movement itself and that it should be looking to itself without exposing itself in public as it has done today, correcting the problems in spite of the provocation and the extreme harassment which its member unions face. One would need to look at the leadership of the trade union movement in both New South Wales and Victoria and, one might also say, the political leadership in New South Wales and Victoria.
—It might be better than in Queensland.

—I point out to Senator Button that Queensland has certain problems which are unique and which are not suffered in New South Wales or Victoria. We have a one-party system in Queensland which is loaded towards the National Party and which we cannot break. We are not likely to get any assistance from Canberra with legislation of this sort, for instance, in trying to correct the situation in Queensland. Perhaps legislation enabling the Government to intrude into the affairs of corporate structures and institutions could be introduced to give us at least the chance of having responsible government in Queensland. I am suggesting that there should be one vote, one value, in other words, give some groups the voting strength they do not have at present and perhaps take it away from certain people in the rural areas who have too heavy a vote.

SPEECH.PARA: I undertook merely to make some short comments on this Bill. I am not the only one who has reservations; there are others less able to speak their minds. It is not a matter of courage; it is just that I am in such a position that retribution does not come as quickly as it would come to others. Sometimes the wrath of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) can be terrible to behold and some may take more note of it than others. I just say that it is very difficult for some of us to be party to deregistering a union. Some of us are perhaps too old to change. Perhaps our background, which set us on the path into this place, was a working class background. Many of the members of the Builders Labourers Federation were born into economic and intellectual poverty. Many of them do not escape. They have only their physical labour to supply. They contribute to the building of structures that lead to the accumulation of great wealth. They seek to participate in that wealth and the leadership has used over-extreme methods to improve their condition.

But it should be understandable that those who work physically and who receive the least in our community should strive to improve their conditions, especially in such a rip-off society as ours. Doctors were able to apply similar methods and to survive, and they continue to survive. Others can demand as much as $1,000 a day for their effort. Just recently we saw the example of the panel of computer advisers for one of the parliamentary committees. The return demanded-I say demanded because they are in an almost closed shop situation by virtue of their skill-was $480 to $1,000 a day. There are people who rip off the Medicare system to such an extent that they can buy football teams at $4.5m. Can honourable senators see why there is such pressure for those below to improve their condition? That is what the Builders Labourers Federation endeavours to do. In Queensland it has done it responsibly but in New South Wales and Victoria there have been some doubts concerning this. But when we bring down legislation of this sort, which will cut across all the endeavours of responsible people to achieve better results, I believe we are going to extremes. I have voiced my opposition and I have taken the time that I indicated I would take. I rest on the points that I have made.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank honourable senators for their support of the Building Industry Bill. In replying on behalf of the Government I certainly do not want to get into that world of sociological schmaltz about which Senator Georges has just been speaking, which sees builders labourers as unique victims of a system who have to respond in a particular way. Of course, that sort of argument does not stand up. He says that the builders labourers in Queensland, whom I suppose he would see as similar victims of the system, do not behave in the same way as builders labourers in New South Wales or Victoria, which has been the subject of discussion in the course of debate in the Senate. Of course, as Senator Georges said, there are all sorts of pressures in a society like this for people to improve their conditions. But the vast majority of members of the trade union movement in Australia do not see it necessary to improve conditions by the same methods as the builders labourers have taken.

SPEECH.PARA: Much has been said in this debate about the Building Industry Bill as well as publicly about the Builders Labourers Federation. I do not want in any sense to get into the rat race of moral outrage against the BLF-outrage which has been expressed for all sorts of different reasons and motivations in pursuing deregistration of the union. The Government's motivations and reasons for bringing this legislation into the Parliament are quite simple. They are that in an industrial sense the BLF has behaved quite irresponsibly. It has resorted to tactics which are not acceptable to Australian society as a whole or to the work force and the trade union movement as a whole. It has failed to honour agreements and undertakings it has made. For those reasons the Government takes the view that this legislation should be introduced so that the question of deregistration of the BLF can be dealt with by the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission.

I do not want to go into the history of this matter. Some of the things which have been said are correct. Senator Walters embarked on a description of what she would call a model course in how to deregister an organisation like the BLF. I remind honourable senators of the model course that was adopted by the Fraser Government. In February 1981 it announced and made a decision to deregister the BLF. In November 1982, nearly two years later, that Government commenced proceedings to deregister the Federation. Throughout those proceedings there was not much consultation with the industry. Indeed, throughout those proceedings, which went on and on, there was little community support for the process which was being engaged in. First, there was no trade union support, and, secondly, it is clear that there was not by any means unanimous employer support. Certainly there were no means of ensuring that employers would not cave into the builders labourers at the slightest whiff of pressure. There was a mass of evidence to the contrary. There was a bad history in terms of deregistration proceedings taken against the BLF by the Fraser Government. It was a mess-up from beginning to end.

As has been said, it is true that the present Government tried over a period of 18 months to two years to bring the BLF within the framework of the industrial arbitration system and the norms of union and industrial behaviour. Numerous attempts were made to do that and failed. There was a dishonouring of agreements and undertakings given by the BLF to both the Government and the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. In that context ultimately the Government determined the present course of action. It arose from that history of a previously failed attempt to deregister the BLF and, secondly, a course of conduct in relation to the present Government and the current conciliation and arbitration system. Senator Walters asked the rhetorical question: Why take it to the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission?

TALK.START.PARA: —You can't think of a reason?
—I am sorry, I have trouble with my eyes sometimes. The honourable senator should not persecute the half blind. I am just trying to read my notes of what she said.
—Have you seen Max Gillies lately?

—Mr Deputy President, I seek the protection of the Chair from the vulgarians opposite. After all, there are young people present in the gallery. Whatever the habits of Opposition senators might be, there is no need to try to inflict them on me. What Senator Walters said was that the Government had backed off and given responsibility to the Arbitration Commission. Of course, that is absolutely correct. Senator Walters was not in the chamber when I was describing what a mess her Government, the Fraser Government, had made of trying to deregister the BLF in the past. This Government does not intend to get into the same mess. This Government is seeking from the Commission a declaration which would be the basis of deregistration. That is an appropriate procedure to follow.
—Are you going to clean up the ETU in Queensland as well?
—I would not think we need worry about that, with a zealot like Senator MacGibbon there. One would think that would happen anyway.
—Could you give us an estimate of how much it has cost the industry in the last five years since you withdrew proceedings-just an estimate of how much it has cost?

—I cannot give that estimate. I can give figures of what it cost companies like the Grollo Brothers and Hersfield's and such companies. It cost them a packet, and it also cost Norm Gallagher a bit. In terms of the cost to industry, I do not know the answer. As Senator Walters herself said, this has been going on for years and years. The point is not so much the cost to industry, but the best method of tackling the problem. The Government supported by Senator Walters totally failed. One can talk about the cost to the community of doctors, politicians and builders labourers and everyone can make a little speech on those issues. The question is how to deal with the problem. That was something Senator Walters did not address her attention to. It is all very well to beat one's chest here and talk about cost and things of that sort, but the question is to find a solution to these problems. That is what this legislation is basically about. There has been a bad history of the matter in terms of the BLF's conduct over a period as well as in respect of governments and arbitration commission attempts to deal with the problem. The solution proposed by the present Government is to seek the deregistration of the BLF after appropriate hearings before the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Walters brought a lot of other issues into the debate. She said that it is the Governments responsibility to protect the population against BLF tactics. In fact, it is not the Government's responsibility. It is largely the responsibility of state governments. All those matters can be discussed in this context of emotional angst but are not particularly relevant to the legislation before the Senate.

I do not think that in the course of the debate any particular points of substance were made by the Opposition. For that reason I do not propose to go into detailed comments made by particular honourable senators. As I said at the beginning of my remarks, we are grateful that, for whatever reasons or bizarre motivations, honourable senators support this legislation. I wish the legislation a speedy passage and commend it to the Senate.

DEBATE.TITLE: ABORIGINAL LAND RIGHTS (NORTHERN TERRITORY) AMENDMENT BILL 1985NATIONAL PARKS AND WILDLIFE CONSERVATION AMENDMENT BILL 1985

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 21 August, on motion by Senator Grimes:
That the Bills be now read a second time.
upon which Senator Peter Baume had moved by way of amendment:
Leave out all words after `That', insert `the Bills be withdrawn and redrafted to provide for-
(a) ownership of the Uluru National Park to be vested in the Northern Territory, subject to:
(i) an agreement ensuring effective Aboriginal involvement in management of the Park, and
(ii) adequate and appropriate portions of the Park being vested by freehold title in Aboriginals for the purposes of living areas;
(b) a right of entry to all persons subject to protection of sacred sites and the Park; and
(c) the Agreement to be entered into between the Director of National Parks and Wildlife and the Land Council not to come into effect until approved by the Parliament'.
