SPEECH.SPEAKER: Robertson Sen E.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Amendment Bill 1985 and the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Amendment Bill 1985 and to reject the amendment. I was not going to participate in the debate. It seemed to me that the Bills were straightforward and were only continuing work that had been in progress for some time. The Uluru Bill recognises ownership and spiritual significance and the Conservation Bill sets up the machinery for the national park. I have been drawn into the debate because of some of the statements which have been made in both Houses. I have at this stage read the speeches from both Houses that are in Hansard so far. I am very gratified to say that the quality remains in the Senate. It is very pleasing to see that this is the case. I do not know why this should be, but it is probably because there is so little time in the other place. Any adjudicator who was assessing the speeches of Senator Peter Baume and Senator Puplick would give them very high scores, particularly if he did not have any background knowledge of the situation. I do not think the speeches would stand up quite so well with those who do know something about the situation. I thought Senator Macklin aptly summed up the two speeches with this comment:

SPEECH.PARA: They have raised what might be seen in one sense to be an ingenious argument but nevertheless trivial.

I think that sums up the propositions that have been put in both places, very effectively in this place and less effectively in the other. Senator Macklin went on to demolish the basis of what he called the ingenious argument. Senator Reynolds called the arguments put forward by Senator Baume and Senator Puplick `opportunistic, cynical exercises to mislead the people of Australia'.

My concern particularly is the change in attitude we have seen in both places, but more particularly in this place, over the 10 years that I have been a senator. On the matter of Aboriginal affairs, previously we had a bipartisan approach and speakers have quoted at great length speakers on both sides of the political spectrum and in both Houses showing the bipartisan approach which has been taken in the past. Honourable senators will recall that when the Opposition was in government for seven or eight years it called for a bipartisan approach and when the present Government was in opposition it co-operated. We acted, as I have said in this place on a number of occasions, as a true opposition. The present Opposition has not yet learnt this lesson. It must do so. I suggest that we will give Opposition members plenty of time in which to do so and they will be able to operate as a true opposition.

The first lesson that needs to be learned is to stick with the principles which are enunciated so clearly by the leaders and by the various spokesmen. This is very hard to do, particularly if the principles happen to be a bit rubbery, like somebody's famous figures. The second lesson one must learn is that one must not manipulate facts to score points in what I call a fourth form debate. The issue before us is far too important for that sort of exercise. By fourth form debate, quite clearly, I am talking about an exercise that might be conducted by adolescents or people in a debating society who are out to exercise their skills of debate rather than trying to arrive at some solution. There is a great deal of evidence that neither of those lessons have been learnt. This is evident in the wording of the amendment.

Senators on both sides of this place have served on the Joint Select Committee on Aboriginal Land Rights in the Northern Territory. In fact, the present Leader of the Opposition (Senator Chaney)-before he became one of the many Ministers for Aboriginal Affairs in the previous Government-led this Committee as a back bencher. One thing that came out very clearly was that the Aboriginal people in the Northern Territory agreed unanimously that land rights, sea rights and all of these connected issues had to remain with the Federal Government; they were not to be given to the Northern Territory Government.

I will not dwell on the reasons why there was this want of trust in the Northern Territory Government. It embarrasses me because although the Government is not of my particular persuasion, it happens to be the Government of a Territory of which I am very proud. This want of trust came before the scandals of the present Government, a government which was headed by the present honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Everingham) in the other place, caused it to be held in such poor esteem. I refer to the patronage of party supporters, the funny money which came from overseas for development, the casino scandal, the patronage of Ministers to assist in the acquisition of businesses, the politicisation of the Public Service and all of those other things. Before all of those scandals, the Aboriginal people of the Northern Territory made it clear that they did not trust the Northern Territory Government and wanted all matters relating to Aboriginal affairs to be referred back to the Federal Government.

I recall that the former Prime Minister, Mr Fraser, also showed a certain reluctance to trust the Northern Territory Government in the present issue under debate. Senators will recall many statements from a plethora of Ministers on this issue. Just to correct an impression from yesterday, there has been only one Minister for Aboriginal Affairs in the present Labor Government. There were quite a number in the previous Government. I have lost count as to how many there were. Those many Ministers supported the protection of sacred sites. They supported the granting of land rights. They were quite clear in their acceptance of the ownership of certain sacred and significant sites. Senator Baume, both when he was Minister and before he was Minister, lectured us on custodianship, managers, traditional owners, traditional users, people with rights to the land, people who could use the land and so on. There was a good understanding on the other side about the ownership and the relationship of land to people. This seems to be all forgotten in the statements which have been made up to date and in the amendment which has been put forward by the same Senator Baume. We now have a situation, we are told, where Uluru is `reverting to Australian ownership'. What an extraordinary statement: The Government is giving it away. I would have thought from the comments that Senator Baume made previously, forgetting the spurious and fourth form arguments he brought up yesterday, that the Government has not the power to give it away, regardless of to whom it was going to give it. Senator Reynolds painted a picture of the monolith being spirited away, like some transplanted Irish castle, to the United States. That made a mockery of the situation being presented by Senator Baume, which was completely ridiculous. After all, is it going to be like the Grand Canyon, the Victoria Falls, Mount Fuji, or the Rocky Mountains? They will remain there to be enjoyed by everyone who goes to see them, whether they be Australian tourists or overseas tourists.

I rather feel that the almighty dollar has raised its head and, to put it in the vernacular, I think that some concern is being expressed on the other side of the chamber about who is going to get the lolly. Is it to be the Aboriginal people generally or specifically? Is it to be the 165,000 people of the Northern Territory? Is it to be the people of Australia in some way? Or is it to be some concession owner on the same principle that operates in another State of Australia, whether he be Japanese or from the United States? This peculiar situation can be demonstrated by a situation I remember in the Northern Territory. I went to a meeting at which someone complained bitterly that the Aboriginal people had locked the gate of a property and prevented him fishing in a particular area. The gate, of course, gave access through the station to that fishing area. He lectured me for about 15 minutes on why he should be allowed to pass through this area-because he was born in the Northern Territory, because he had fished there for many years, and so on. I waited until he had finished and then I said: `That land is not owned by Aboriginal people. It is owned by a Chinese gentleman'. The extraordinary response came back: `Oh, that is all right then'. I wonder whether that is the attitude which is developing on the other side of this chamber-it does not matter who gets it as long as the Aboriginal people do not get it.

A second question which might raise its head is: Who will decide which areas can be opened up for inspection or can be photographed? The Opposition, in one of its contributions, tried to sell the situation of a little old lady not being allowed to take a sunset shot with her Kodak. Members of the Opposition did not dwell on the real situation of intrusion by the media. We all know that members of the media must get a story regardless of who is hurt or embarrassed or what false or fake incident is structured to enable them to do so. Is it any wonder that people are cautious. The word `people' raises the old and hoary chestnut we have heard yet again from both chambers-the white advisers. White advisers are becoming as common as reds under the bed. Of course, white advisers are assisting the Aboriginal people, just as they assist me. I have white advisers assisting me. I have an electorate assistant, an accountant, a doctor and a lawyer. All these white advisers help me to do those things which I cannot do myself. But no one pretends that that is because I have not the ability to make decisions in areas where I have some expertise.

Let us lay this to rest once, and, I hope, for all time. Those Aboriginal people who are charged with decision making do it well. I might just raise this question: What percentage of the European population is involved in decision making? I remind the Senate that being white does not make anyone infallible. By the same token being black does not make anyone infallible. There is the same range of ability and the same range of intelligence in both groups. I wanted to make many other comments, but I understand that we are trying to achieve the passage of this legislation before lunch time. I leave it to my colleague the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) to make further comments on points raised by members of the Opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating amendments to the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act and to the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act, the purpose of which is to enable the Government to grant title to the Uluru area to the traditional owners. There has been extensive criticism of the legislation by members of the Opposition. I will comment on some of it, but much of it has been quite irrelevant. Much of the criticism stemming from the Opposition has concerned itself with predictions that are simply not based on any possible outcome of the legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: The fundamental opposition to the Bills from the Liberal Party in particular and from the Opposition in general is quite incomprehensible to me because the arrangement that this legislation proposes for the Uluru area is exactly the same as the Liberal-National Party Government introduced in 1979 for the management of the Kakadu National Park. To its credit, in 1979 that Government made arrangements whereby the title of the Kakadu National Park area went to the traditional Aboriginal owners but the park was then leased back by its owners to the National Parks and Wildlife Service to be a national park. I might say in passing that it is the most splendid national park I have ever seen. Its management is excellent and incorporates efforts by Aboriginal traditional owners, some of whom work as rangers in the park, as well as by non-Aboriginal park rangers from the National Parks and Wildlife Service.

That was a very successful arrangement, and we are now proposing to make the same arrangement for the Uluru area. In exactly the same way the title will go to a trust which represents the traditional owners and the park will be leased back to the National Parks and Wildlife Service to be a national park, probably of such splendour and interest that it will vie with the Kakadu National Park. It is very hard for me, trying to take a rational approach to the Opposition's position on this, to see any reason at all why the Opposition should be critical of these arrangements. Certainly there is no justification for the very melodramatic claims some Opposition senators have made about Australians losing this area, about Australians being denied access to it, about what was part of our natural heritage being controlled by very few people, and so on. There is absolutely no basis in our legislation for these criticisms and, therefore, I do not think they warrant a considered or lengthy reply.

I would like to comment on some of the matters that Senator Peter Baume raised. He claimed that the Uluru claim has not been subjected to judicial process by the Aboriginal Land Commissioner. There may be something in that claim in a legal and technical sense, but it is important to remember that Mr Justice Toohey, the Aboriginal Land Commissioner, said:

Both places (Uluru and Katatjuta) are of enormous significance, not only for the local desert groups immediately responsible for them, but for the claimants generally and for a wider range of Aboriginal people . . . There is an unreality in dealing with the claim area divorced from the National Park, not the least when considering the matter of traditional attachments. The attachment of all Aboriginal witnesses was obvious.

The advantages of a grant (i.e. exclusive of the Park) lie mainly in the recognition of traditional ownership for members of a tribal group engaged in trying to secure a wider recognition when the land of the greatest significance is not available to be claimed under the Act.

It is quite clear that the decision put forward in this legislation is completely in keeping with Mr Justice Toohey's assessment of the significance of the land. As I said, there were extensive claims that the land is being taken from Australians, and I think that claim is really so absurd as not to warrant any lengthy response.

However, a claim was also made by several Opposition senators that the title will be given to just one community, the Mutitjulu community. I would like to place on record that that claim is not right. What is happening is that an Uluru-Katatjuta land trust is being established to hold title on behalf of a much wider group identified by Mr Justice Toohey and other Aboriginals with traditional rights in the land.

Senator Puplick made an issue of the fact that Mr Justice Toohey did not refer to Uluru in his 1983 report entitled `Seven Years On'. Of course, Mr Justice Toohey did not refer to that because his terms of reference called for him to deal with operational difficulties with the Act and it would have been improper of the judge to comment on such matters as Uluru.

I would also like to point out that the agreements reached with Aboriginals in respect of the Uluru National Park provide for the establishment of an Uluru board of 11 members, consisting of six Aboriginals nominated by the traditional owners, plus the Director of National Parks and Wildlife, one other Commonwealth official nominated by the responsible Minister, one representative of the tourist industry nominated by the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism and two representatives of the Northern Territory. So, it should be quite obvious to honourable senators that the Bill establishes co-operative management arrangements under which the Director of National Parks and Wildlife and the traditional owners will work in partnership with the advice of the tourist industry and the Northern Territory representatives on the board. There is no reason to believe that this will not lead to effective management of the park.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the Director accept the majority decisions of the board?

—I will come back to that particular detail during the Committee stage. It is quite clear that it will be a well balanced board. It is one that will give a proper opportunity for all legitimate interests to be expressed. The ultimate authority over the park is not, as Senator Peter Baume claimed, with the Director of National Parks and Wildlife. It is in fact with the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment. After all, the ultimate authority for the administration of Commonwealth legislation is with Commonwealth Ministers. This is a fact of political and constitutional life with which Senator Baume is quite familiar.

SPEECH.PARA: The lease-back arrangement is specifically designed to ensure that the Uluru National Park continues to be accessible to all Australians. The alternative arrangement proposed by some Opposition senators, namely, that the management should be by the Northern Territory Government, is quite illogical. After all, the Australian Government represents all Australians; the Northern Territory Government represents about 100,000 Australians, which is just a tiny percentage of the population. It is clearly illogical to suggest that we would have a structure for a more accessible and more appropriate national management of the park by handing it over to the tiny administration which represents a tiny number of people.

I shall address in detail at the Committee stage the proper concerns that have been raised during the second reading debate. However, at this stage of the debate I would like to say that the legislation which is now before the Senate is within the spirit of our Government's land rights policy. It is clearly within the spirit and the act of the Liberal and National parties' land rights policy when they were in government. At least this was the case in 1979 when the then Government made exactly the same arrangements for the Kakadu National Park. The arrangements for the Kakadu National Park have been of benefit to all Australians and, I might add, to those international visitors who have been fortunate enough to visit that superb place. There is no reason to believe that the Uluru National Park will be any less a national treasure or any less an attraction for international tourists. In fact, given the substantive investment in the very high quality tourist facilities in the area, it wil probably outdo the Kakadu National Park in terms of attracting people from all over Australia and all over the world. What we are seeing is a very progressive and exciting move. I hope at this stage that the Opposition might rethink its position and respond positively to what, after all, is a further development of one of the good things that it set in train when it was in office.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Mr President, I want to make a personal explanation. I missed the division on the question that the two Bills be read a second time. I want to explain that I had every intention of voting against those two Bills, as I indicated in my speech at the second reading stage, but due to a mishap I failed to get to the division.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Amendment Bill, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 12, the Schedule, leave out the amendment of sub-section 7 (11A).

The amendment in question relates to the designation of a region. The amendment to sub-section 7 (11A) would give the Commonwealth power to extend parks within the region which the Commonwealth has defined to include not only the Alligator Rivers region but also Uluru. Within that region the parks could be extended without any need for public notice being given. This provision would remove the public's right to make representations under section 11 in respect of such extensions or additions to existing parks and reserves or wildlife zones. We are concerned that as a result of this part of the Schedule the public would lose its right, first, to be informed by notice and, secondly, to make representations as it presently has the right to do. The effect of this part of the Schedule is to limit rights, which the public has at present, should a government wish to vary a park.

The present scheme is that the Governor-General is empowered to declare by declaration an area to be a park, reserve or wilderness zone under the appropriate section of the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act. However, before His Excellency can make such a proclamation-except after consideration by the Executive Council of a report by the Director of National Parks and Wildlife-the Director is obliged to give public notice of the nature of the report and of any recommendations therein. We are concerned that that requirement to give public notice should remain. The Director must also invite people to make representations on the report, giving not less than 60 days notice after the date of publication of notice of the Act.

I refer honourable senators who may be interested to subsection 7 (12) (a) (i) and subsection 7 (12) (a) (ii) of the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act. The effect of these amendments, which appear under the innocuous heading `Minor amendments of Principal Act' that appears in the Schedule of the Act which is being considered by the Committee, is to repeal sub-section 7 (11A) of the principal Act and substitute that with the proposed new sub-section which is before us. We are concerned that as a result of this we now know, first, that the word `region' which is used by the Government now includes together the Alligator Rivers region and Uluru as part of the same region, when it is clearly not a geographical region. It is clearly some notional region within which special rules will apply. That is the key to it-it is a region within which special rules will apply. There is nothing physical about that region including the Alligator Rivers region and Uluru. The net result of the proposed new sub-section 7 (11A) will be that the Commonwealth may add to existing parks and reserves any area within the region so defined. The Government will not have to give public notice and public comment will no longer be necessary. The Government will not have to give the 60 days notice and call for public comment.

We have had no explanation as to why that limitation of existing rights of the public is either necessary or desirable. Presumably, the requirement for the Director to give notice was to ensure that the public was informed and advised of what was to happen. The requirement for the public to be able to make comment was a protection for the public. There is no real reason why, in the terms of this Act, which relates really to the granting to a particular group of title over Uluru and the Olgas, this amendment is necessary. There has been no explanation as to why it is desirable to limit the rights of the public in this area. It happens that this new sub-section may also have the effect of removing the rights of a group, say, the Northern Territory, to seek judicial review of a decision of the Commonwealth or of the Director.

I merely observe that the political wheel turns; that it is inevitable that, some time not too far in the future, there will be a Liberal or National Party Minister administering the Act. In removing the rights of the public to be informed and to make submissions while a Labor Government is in power, one needs to consider the fact than when a Liberal or National Party Government is in power one may be concerned at what one has done to limit the rights of the public should one wish to vary or extend a national park. We cannot understand the merit of or the necessity for this amendment to the Schedule. I have moved my amendment. I invite the Minister to tell us why it is necessary for this amendment to the Act to have been made. As the Bill says, it is a minor amendment to the Act. Why is it necessary for this to be done? Why has it been necessary for the Government to move to make the giving of notice and the seeking of comment unnecesary?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —This amendment deals with one of the two substantial changes to the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act 1975 which were not raised in the second reading debate, which dealt largely with the question of Aboriginal land rights and of Uluru in particular. The National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Amendment Bill does two things which are of significance as far as the Opposition amendment is concerned. The first is that it removes the old definition of what was the region over which the Act applied and substitutes a new definition of region. Whereas previously the region was that prescribed under the Enviroment Protection (Alligator Rivers Region) Act 1978 and the areas of Mount Bundey, Goodparla, Gimbat and Eva Valley, to that is now added the Uluru area as described in the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976. The second thing is that it removes the old regime about the way in which additions and variations to the parks within the region could be made. As Senator Peter Baume has said, it does so by pretending to be a minor amendment listed in the Schedule. The Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment, Mr Cohen, in the debate in the House of Representatives on 20 May 1985 said:

SPEECH.PARA: He--
he was referring to Mr Connolly, the Opposition Shadow Minister-
referred to sub-section 7 (11A) which, as he points out quite correctly, applies to Kakadu National Park as well as to the Uluru National Park.
He went on to state in another part of his comment:
The amendment would also enable land already in a park or reserve to be incorporated in another park or reserve without the need for public representations.

This potential interchange between parks and areas within the region has considerable implications as far as the Parliament itself is concerned. Having adopted a plan of management for a particular park or reserve, we could find land in one particular park or reserve taken out and given a different definition and is no longer subject to the management plan which the Commonwealth Parliament approved. Land could be taken out of one area of management plan and added to another area of management plan. It seems to me quite extraordinary that that should be done under a cloak of secrecy. That is the effect of the new regime which the Bill substitutes as a result of the amendment to sub-section 7 (11A) proposed in the Schedule.

This Government is getting a considerable record in terms of attempting to do various things covertly and by secret means. It has already made its own assaults upon the Freedom of Information Act and the ability of people to get information about what the Government is doing, either by proscribing things from the Act or by making increases in charges so that people cannot get access to the information. It is now taking away from the existing regime the right of the public to make comment about a particular variation in the arrangements for national parks in the Northern Territory region redefined by the amendment Bill. It seems extraordinary to me that a government which tries to pretend that it is in favour of information and consultation now introduces into an amending Bill a regime which allows changes and variations to be made and not be subject to the process of public scrutiny, public information and public discussion. It seems to me quite extraordinary that, given what the Government has sought to portray to the public about its commitment to open government, freedom of information and public consultation, it should now introduce, by way of the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Amendment Bill, a derogation of the right of the public to be informed and to participate in discussions about changes within the region-changes not only in the management structure but also in the very definition of the national parks which are to be the subject of this legislation.

I will not take up any more of the time of the Committee, but if honourable senators look at the extension of exactly what is prescribed in new sub-section 7 (11A), its impact upon Aboriginal land and its impact upon the seas surrounding the defined park areas, I think they will find that this is a major change, tarted up in terms of a minor amendment to a Schedule, which will have very deleterious effects not only on the management of the park system in the Northern Territory but also in terms of the public support and respect for the way in which park management plans are drawn up and the way in which the Parliament is entitled to approve or disapprove those park management plans when the region of the park itself is then subject to alteration without consultation with the public and without the approval of the Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I respond to the questions raised by Senator Peter Baume and Senator Puplick about sub-section 7 (11A) and the amendment, I would like to respond to a question that Senator Peter Baume raised by way of interjection during the completion of the second reading debate. He asked about the decision-making process of the Board. He asked specifically whether the Director would accept a majority decision or would be able to overrule the Board. The Director will not be able to overrule the Board. The Director, as a member of the Board, would normally accept majority decisions of the Board, but the Bill provides for all circumstances and so establishes procedures for resolving conflict between the Director and the Board. These procedures are likely to be used very rarely, if at all. The traditional Aboriginal owners have indicated support for these procedures and there is every reason to expect, particularly in the light of the excellent record of the relationship between the Director and the traditional owners in Kakadu, that operations of the Board will be conducted in a co-operative atmosphere and that decisions will be reached by consensus. The conflict resolution procedure was set out by the Minister in the second reading speech.

SPEECH.PARA: I now move to the more complicated matter of our amendment to sub-section 7 (11A). The Fraser Government introduced the present sub-section 7 (11A) in 1978. The intention of that action was to implement a recommendation of the Ranger Uranium Environmental Inquiry that declaration of national park within the region should be exempt from public representation requirements. The justification was that considerable public discussion had already taken place during, and preceding, the inquiry.

Recent legal advice has suggested that sub-section 7 (11A) could exempt from public comment proclamations not only creating parks within the region but also removing land from parks. This interpretation conflicts with the intention of the sub-section. The Government's amendment expresses the original intention of sub-section 7 (11A) by clearly providing that the exemption from public representations will not apply to proclamations whereby land would cease to be park or reserve. Furthermore, only land within the region could be made park or reserve without public representations as was the case under the Fraser Government's original sub-section 7 (11A).

The amendment would also enable land already in a park or reserve to be incorporated in another park or reserve without the need for public representations. This provision would apply only where the status of land would not be changed by proclamation. Senator Puplick raised objections to this. For example, Kakadu stage 1 and stage 2 could be made one park under the Government's proposal for the purpose of having one plan of management. Senator Puplick raised concerns about the absence of a need for public representation should such a change take place. I point out to Senator Puplick that the plans of management for all parks including parks whose boundaries would be increased if this amendment were passed would be managed under the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act. Therefore the plans would be made available for public comment and would be laid before both Houses of Parliament before being adopted. If the two parks were to be joined and there were to be a new plan of management, that would under the terms of the present National Parks and Wildlife Act, be made available for public comment and brought to this and the other place. I hope that answers Senator Puplick's concern. It is also important to point out that the provision under the Act which would enable parks within the region to be joined into one park would apply only when the status of the land would not be claimed by proclamation. In other words where there are already parks, two parks could be made into one park; thus the procedures which I have just set out would apply.

Both Senator Peter Baume and Senator Puplick raised the matter of including Uluru in the definition of a region. This provides a simple means of extending to the Uluru National Park the existing provisions of the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act relating to Aboriginal matters and Aboriginal land. Because Uluru is already a national park including it in the region would not significantly alter public participation procedures. The only effect this action would have on public participation in Uluru would be to remove the need for public representations on the inclusion of seven small enclaves in the park. However-I think this is an important point-public representations on this action, that is on the seven small enclaves, have already been invited and received. The seven enclaves amount to only 16 hectares out of the total area of Uluru National Park of 132,500 hectares. Extending the region to include Uluru as proposed in the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Amendment Bill would not allow any further extension of Uluru National Park without full public participation as presently required by the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act.

The possibility of a judicial review of decisions arising from this position was raised by Senator Puplick. It was not clear from his question which decision he would wish to have a judicial review of. I point out to Senator Puplick that the only substantive change to park boundaries that this amendment would facilitate is the addition to Uluru National Park of the seven small enclaves that I have just referred to-that is the 16 hectares-about which public comment has already been sought. Principally, the amendment clarifies present section 7 (11A) which is vaguely worded.
Amendment negatived.
Consideration interrupted.
Sitting suspended from 12.45 to 2 p.m.

—Is the Leader of the Government in the Senate aware that the Leader of the Opposition has indicated in his Budget reply speech that a Liberal government would sell off government enterprises such as the Australian Industry Development Corporation, Medibank Private and the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation and would look to sell off the Commonwealth Bank, Trans Australia Airlines, Aussat Pty Ltd, the Australian National Line and all other government bodies? —Efficiency.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hardly have to answer the question because Senator Messner has said that it means efficiency. Yes, I did see the Opposition Leader's Budget reply which contained a commitment to a comprehensive program of selling out Australian public enterprise. ANSWER.PARA: It is all very well to say we will privatise this and we will do that and fiddle about. That's all fiddling with the edges.

Privatisation of Telecom and Australia Post-

Senator Missen was articulating the winter of the Liberals' discontent. The winter of that discontent was made glorious summer this morning by Mr Steele Hall, that son of the Yorke Peninsula, when he said in an address, I think at Canberra Grammar School:

These comments contrast strangely with some of the heady rhetoric of the speeches the Liberal Party's national conference by people such as Senator Jim Short, Mr John Howard and Mr Jim Carlton.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. I have no doubt that the Leader of the Government could discourse for 60 minutes on his views on the Liberal Party, but I suggest that has little to do with his ministerial responsibility. I also suggest, Mr President, that he is debating the question and that you should call him to order and get him to sit down.

—I know that Senator Button is within the confines of answering the question but I tend to think that he is reaching the stage of debating the subject raised in the question. I ask him to try to shorten his answer as much as possible.

—Mr President, with the greatest respect, what I was drawing the Senate's attention to was that a lot of other people are debating this question. The outcome of that debate is very important for this country and very interesting. Privatisation is not about small government as some people allege; it is not about cutting taxes in some sort of fire sale mentality; it is all about the ideological obsessions of a Liberal leader incapable of understanding economic policy and with a dwindling grasp of the leadership of his own Party. That is what it is all about. It is most unfortunate that in the context of a very important Budget--
—Why did you do it in the mini-Budget?
—Order! I have asked the Leader of the Government to restrict his answer. I ask Senator Rae to cease interjecting.

—I conclude by saying that it is most unfortunate that within the context of an important Budget concerned with economic growth in this country the Leader of the purported Opposition should devote so much time to pursuing this ridiculous red herring which has been intruded into an otherwise very important debate.

—I ask the Minister for Veterans' Affairs to explain under what criteria members of the Council of the Australian War Memorial are selected? I ask this question in the light of recent changes to the composition of the Council resulting in the removal of Admiral Sir Anthony Synnot not only from the chairmanship but also from the Council. Does the Minister agree that this is an extraordinary action in light of past practice where one member of the Council has always been a distinguished and or senior ex-service person? Does this not imply criticism by the Minister of Sir Anthony's performance, considered more than adequate as Chief of the Defence Force Staff, bearing in mind that Sir Anthony was available for reappointment?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The criteria that I apply for any appointment are that the person should be, first, competent; secondly, representative; and thirdly, able to carry out public functions. In respect of the appointments that I made for 1985-88, the Senate might be interested to hear that Sir William Keys was reappointed. He is the National President of the Returned Services League. Dame Beryl Beaurepaire, who is very active in the Opposition parties and a very well known Australian citizen, was reappointed. Mr Bevan Bradbury from the business sector, G. J. Coles and Co. Ltd, and Mr Ken Fry, the former member for Fraser, were appointed. Captain Saunders, the first Australian Aborigine to receive a commissioned rank in World War II, was appointed, as was Mr Brian McMullan, the General Secretary of the Australian Public Service Association.

ANSWER.PARA: All those persons were veterans, members of the armed forces during World War II. Therefore, they met an important criterion that they have a natural and abiding interest in the functions of the Australian War Memorial. The implication that we have done something improper in not appointing senior officers of the armed forces to a position ought to be discarded, for the simple reason that the armed forces are represented in their own right. The Army, Navy and Air Force have their own representatives by way of the chiefs of the particular sections of the armed forces. Therefore, I do not believe that the War Memorial is affected in any way by the appointment.

I remind those who believe that the War Memorial should have representatives of the senior ranks of the armed services and the Senate of the comments of Field Marshal Lord Wavell who said that the strategy and tactics of war are really absurdly simple. It is the actualities, the hunger, the fear, the tiredness, the lack of sleep and the actual warfare that make war so complicated. That indicates that it is the ordinary citizens who perform the functions during periods of conflict. I was particularly interested in getting more balance in the way in which the War Memorial operated, not because I deprecate the activities of former chairmen of the board, or other senior officers, who have performed that function in the past.

However, I was disappointed during my trip to war cemeteries in France and Belgium to find on memorials tributes which read: `To the officers, the non-commissioned officers and the men of the armed forces in World War I', when they should have been tributes to all those who served, not emphasising the officers and the NCOs, and placing the men in a tertiary position. One wonders why so much emphasis is placed on this appointment. When the Australian War Memorial met it chose Dame Beryl Beaurepaire as its Chairman for the whole period from 1985 to 1988. That is a tribute to the capacity of the Memorial to carry out its proper function.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a simple supplementary question. In what way do the new appointees meet the three self-imposed criteria laid down by the Minister better than Admiral Sir Anthony Synnot?

—As I indicated to Admiral Synnot, I have placed on record my appreciation of his service in that position. In no way does his failure to be reappointed represent any criticism of his membership of the board or his activities as the Chairman or as a very important person in the Australian armed forces. It is the prerogative of governments and Ministers to make changes from time to time. I do not resile from that responsibility.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. What provision is being made in the new youth package for those young people who have previously been reliant upon transitional allowances in order to take advantage of programs such as the participation and equity program and other technical and further education bridging courses? Are there any plans for extensions of these courses which cater for the disadvantaged youth who are unlikely otherwise ever to qualify for traineeships?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The major purpose of the Government's strategy for young people is to increase their access to employment training and education. Improvements in the job market and school participation rates, together with new opportunities available under employment and training programs, particularly traineeships, will provide more young people with the necessary skills to participate effectively in the work force.

ANSWER.PARA: The introduction of traineeships will see some 10,000 early school leavers take up a structured training program in 1985-86, rising to some 75,000 by 1988-89. —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. Has the Government noted reports that the Philippines military was involved in the massacre of a parish leader and his four sons in Father Brian Gore's former parish in Negros? Is it a fact that some $1.5m has been allocated in this year's Budget for defence co-operation with the Philippines? What assurance can the Minister give that Australian taxpayers are not aiding and abetting cruel and deadly repression by the military arm of the corrupt Marcos regime?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has heard reports of the murder of a parish leader and his four sons in Negros. Such reports are monitored regularly by our Embassy in Manila and by the Department of Foreign Affairs. I have no further information at the moment about the circumstances of that murder. If and when it comes to hand I will advise Senator Tate and the Senate accordingly. TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. I refer to the lengthy search of the luggage of the Premier of Queensland by Customs officers earlier this month and to the questions which have been raised about who instigated the search. The Minister has been reported as saying that he would obtain a report on the incident. I ask: Has the Minister received the report? Does the report indicate how and why the search was instigated? Can the Minister advise the Senate of the facts and, further, assure the Senate that there has been no victimisation or unfair treatment of the Queensland Premier?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of all the publicity which this Mickey Mouse incident received, I thought the most bizarre allegation which floated up was that I was in some way involved. Having said that, let me try to describe what happened. As I understand it, Sir Joh and Lady Bjelke-Petersen returned from overseas on a flight which arrived at 6.40 a.m. in the morning and were cleared by Customs at 7.44 a.m.
—In the morning?

—The same morning. In the course of discussion with Customs officers Senator Bjelke-Petersen indicated to the aircraft inspector that the baggage contained some goods which were possibly dutiable and chocolates which might be subject to quarantine. As I recall it, this discussion took place after Sir Joh and Lady Bjelke-Petersen had omitted to sign their Customs declarations and had received some assistance with that from a Customs officer. In the course of the baggage examination which followed the conversation between Senator Bjelke-Petersen and the Customs officer a quantity of seeds was discovered and referred to a quarantine officer. Preliminary quarantine advice obtained thereafter was that the seeds were of `a tree seed species not usually restricted'. But further analysis was required to confirm this and the seeds were subsequently referred to the plant quarantine authority in Queensland. Advice was received by Customs from that authority on 8 August 1985 that the seeds were native to Australia, and the release of the seeds was then granted.

ANSWER.PARA: It is normal practice for Customs officers to question the declarants when undeclared quarantine goods are found. This was not done at the time and there is no clear indication of why this was not the case. However, I am advised that it was probably due to the preliminary quarantine advice that the seeds were unlikely to be restricted goods. No action is contemplated under either the Customs Act or the Quarantine Act, the main reasons being that the seeds are of Australian origin, that the declarant was unaware of their presence in the baggage and that there were indications that the seeds had been present in the Premier's bag for some time. The seeds have been returned to the Premier and he and Senator Bjelke-Petersen have been advised by the Collector of Customs that no further action is contemplated. The decision by the Australian Customs Service not to proceed to further action is consistent with normal guidelines and would apply equally to any citizen in similar circumstances.

I had occasion to say at the time of this incident that if there were any lessons to be learned from it by anybody they were that, first of all, returning travellers should sign their Customs declaration; secondly, they should read their Customs declaration; and, thirdly, they should realise that all citizens in this country, whoever they might be, are treated by the Customs Service in an appropriately equal way.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his answer and acknowledge the final point that he made, which would be the view of the Opposition. The Minister may have answered my question inferentially but I have specifically asked him why the search was instigated. Does his answer mean that it flowed from the facts that he has given us? Were any other factors involved? Has he checked that? Can he give me an answer to that explicit question?

—There is no point in my checking that information further. I think I understand the circumstances. I just make the point that Customs officers are under an obligation to search all bags. That is their obligation. They may depart from the exercise of that obligation in some circumstances and, of course, thus usually do. The question of whether bags are to be searched is dictated by two things: First of all, the random sampling system which throws up particular passengers for search; and, secondly, a subjective judgment made by the Customs officer in charge at the time.
—In this case?

—Yes, made by him at a particular time. It is my understanding that the search was instigated largely on the basis of a conversation with Senator Bjelke-Petersen when she informed the Customs officers about chocolates and other possibly dutiable goods.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Trade. Is the Minister aware of the United States `bonus' export program for agricultural trade? Does the Minister believe that this program will unduly affect Australia's agricultural exports, notably wheat, as the Australian Wheat Board estimates that one-third of Australia's wheat export income, $2.5 billion, could be lost? The United States Government recently announced the allocation of 500,000 tonnes of wheat to Egypt under this scheme. What is being done to ensure that Australian wheat exports to Egypt and other markets are not damaged by this scheme?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Following the announcement of a $2 billion export enhancement program for agricultural products by the United States Administration, the Government's concerns about the implications of the program were transmitted to the President of the United States by the Prime Minister and during ministerial discussions with the United States Secretaries of State and Agriculture. The Australian Government was given assurances by the United States Administration that the EEP-the export enhancement program- will be targetted against subsidising competitors, and that the United States will be making it clear to recipient countries that it expects non-subsidised commercial trade to be maintained. Further sales under the program will be subject to this expectation being met. These assurances given by the United States Government are particularly important to Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: Following the last announced intiative by the Americans to target Egypt, the Minister for Primary Industry again expressed our concerns to the United States Secretary of Agriculture, indicating that it will result in downward pressure on wheat prices and is contrary to the key objective of targetting only subsidised exports. Secretary Block again reassured us that the United States had taken careful precautions to ensure that our wheat trade would be protected. No sales under the program have yet been made by the United States. Nevertheless, we are concerned at the possible implications on our wheat trade. The Government is closely monitoring the situation and maintaining close contact with the United States Government. The implications of Senator Richardson's question are that we are caught in a nasty little trade war between the European agricultural community and the United States and that the backlash can be significant for Australia. I think the best summation of the answer is that the Government is very conscious of the situation and is continually making representations to the United States Government about it.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry. I refer to Budget information and media headlines which have applauded the fact that rural industry has received an increased allocation of a very generous $117m. Wheat growers, however, claim that included in that amount is $104.6m which was in fact their own funds which were in hand in the previous financial year and could have been paid out in that year. I therefore ask the Minister: Was $104.6m of the increased rural industry budget allocation in fact wheat growers' own funds? Were these funds held over from last financial year and paid out on 1 July? Was the increase in rural industry funding for 1985-86 in fact only $12.4m?

—One thing I will not accept responsibility for is the way in which the Press reports any item of news at all. I am not sure whether the figure is $104m. At least $100m from the Wheat Finance Fund has been paid out in this financial year-indeed, it was paid out on 1 July. The history of the $100m is that when in 1980 the Fraser Government abolished effectively the wheat stabilisation scheme there was a grower fund to which growers had contributed and from which, subject to certain criteria being fulfilled, payments were made back to wheat growers. It was raised by a grower levy. When the Fraser Government effectively abolished the stabilisation fund it chose, however, not to refund the last $100m of grower contributions which were then in it. It set up some typically dodgy piece of cosmetic accounting under the name of the Wheat Finance Fund under which that $100m, for which there was no longer any justification for retention, was advanced to the Wheat Board as a loan to make the first advance payments to growers. I stress that ever since 1980 the reason for which the $100m had originally been collected from wheat growers has no longer been applicable. It was typical of the sort of cosmetic, shonky accounting devices in which the Fraser Government specialised in order to reduce artificially its outlays and deficits. This Government decided it was time that the money was returned to the wheat growers from whom it was originally raised. That was done on 1 July.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

Is it not a fact that this company seeks to gain monopoly control over certain aspects of this and related technologies for sale under lucrative royalty arrangements in the United States, whose Government has long since imposed a ban on human embryo experimentation for funding purposes? Given the responsibilities of the Commonwealth on patents and related questions, what action does the Government propose to take in face of this commercial exploitation? Further, I ask what action the Attorney proposes to take on the report of the Family Law Council, tabled in Parliament yesterday, which was based on the findings of its sub-committee which inquired into the matter and in relation to which Council Chairman, Mr Justice Fogarty, said to Mr Bowen:

QUESTION.PARA: The Council supports the recommendations which would prohibit the production of human embryos for the sole purpose of research/experimentation or the use of spare human embryos for that purpose . . .

TALK.START.PARA: —As to the latter part of the question, I am advised that the Attorney-General has asked his Department to consult with other departments as a matter of priority to assist in the formulation of the Government's response to the report-a response which clearly has not yet been formulated. We understand that the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs is also considering certain issues relating to reproductive technology. As to the first part of Senator Harradine's question, I will simply have to take it on notice and seek a reply to him at the earliest opportunity.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Trade. It follows his response to Senator Richardson, all of which I did not hear. In 1983-84 our sales were valued at $303m, and in 1984-85 $411m-and in that year involved slightly over two million tonnes. In light of the number of major wheat producers in the world seeking to court Egypt as a major buyer from them, can the Minister say whether the Australian Wheat Board has one full time representative in Cairo?
—No, I cannot tell Senator Crichton-Browne that. I will find out.
—As a supplementary question, I ask Senator Button whether he would be surprised to learn that there are none.
